topic_name: Organic Chemistry: Some Basic Principles and Techniques

canonical_explanation.text: Organic chemistry is the study of compounds of carbon, which form the basis of all living organisms and many synthetic materials. Carbon is unique because of its tetravalency, catenation (ability to form long chains), and capacity to form multiple bonds. Organic compounds are classified based on their functional groups into families such as alkanes, alkenes, alkynes, alcohols, aldehydes, ketones, carboxylic acids, and amines. The IUPAC system provides a systematic method for naming compounds by identifying the longest carbon chain, numbering it to give substituents the lowest locants, and using standard prefixes and suffixes. Isomerism occurs when two or more compounds share the same molecular formula but differ in structure or spatial arrangement. Structural isomers differ in connectivity (chain, position, functional group, metamerism, and tautomerism), while stereoisomers differ in spatial arrangement (geometrical and optical isomerism). Electronic effects profoundly influence the reactivity of organic molecules. The inductive effect is the permanent displacement of sigma-bond electrons toward or away from an electronegative atom. The resonance (mesomeric) effect involves delocalisation of pi electrons across conjugated systems. Hyperconjugation is a stabilising interaction between a filled C-H sigma orbital and an adjacent empty or partially filled p orbital. The electromeric effect is a temporary complete transfer of pi electrons to one atom under the influence of an attacking reagent. Reaction intermediates are short-lived, highly reactive species formed during the course of a reaction. Carbocations are electron-deficient carbon species stabilised by hyperconjugation and resonance; carbanions carry a lone pair on carbon and are stabilised by electron-withdrawing groups; free radicals have an unpaired electron and are stabilised by hyperconjugation and resonance; carbenes have a divalent carbon with two non-bonding electrons. Purification methods include distillation, crystallisation, sublimation, differential extraction, and chromatography. Qualitative analysis detects elements (Lassaigne's test for N, S, halogens), while quantitative analysis determines percentage composition via Dumas method (nitrogen), Carius method (halogens, sulphur, phosphorus), and Liebig's method (carbon and hydrogen).
rules: Carbon exhibits tetravalency, catenation, and the ability to form multiple bonds.
IUPAC naming: identify the longest chain, number to give lowest locants, use proper prefixes/suffixes for substituents and functional groups.
Structural isomers share the same molecular formula but differ in connectivity of atoms.
Stereoisomers have the same connectivity but differ in spatial arrangement (geometrical or optical).
Inductive effect: permanent polarisation of sigma bonds; +I groups donate electrons, −I groups withdraw electrons.
Resonance effect: delocalisation of pi electrons over conjugated systems lowers energy and increases stability.
Hyperconjugation: no-bond resonance between C-H sigma bonds and adjacent empty p orbital; stabilises carbocations and alkenes.
Electromeric effect: temporary complete shift of pi electrons in the presence of an attacking reagent.
Carbocation stability order: 3° > 2° > 1° > methyl (due to hyperconjugation and inductive effects).
Lassaigne's test: fuse organic compound with sodium to convert N, S, halogens to ionic form for detection.
Chromatography separates mixtures based on differential adsorption or partition between stationary and mobile phases.
Quantitative analysis: Dumas method for nitrogen (as N₂), Carius method for halogens/S/P, Liebig method for C and H.

questions.question_text: The unique property of carbon that allows it to form long chains with other carbon atoms is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Catenation is the ability of carbon atoms to bond with other carbon atoms to form long chains, branched chains, and rings. This is due to the strong C–C bond (bond energy ~348 kJ/mol).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Electronegativity is the tendency to attract shared electrons. Isomerism is the phenomenon of having multiple structures for the same molecular formula. Polymerisation is the joining of monomers. None of these specifically describe the chain-forming ability of carbon.

questions.question_text: According to IUPAC nomenclature, the compound CH₃CH₂CH(CH₃)CH₂CH₃ is named:
questions.explanation_correct: The longest chain has 5 carbons (pentane). The methyl substituent is on carbon 3 (numbering to give the lowest locant). Hence, the correct name is 3-methylpentane.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 2-Methylpentane would place the methyl group on C-2, which does not match this structure. '2-Ethylbutane' incorrectly selects a shorter parent chain. 'Isohexane' is a common name and not IUPAC nomenclature.

questions.question_text: The suffix used in IUPAC naming for an aldehyde functional group is:
questions.explanation_correct: In IUPAC nomenclature, the suffix '-al' is used for aldehydes (e.g., methanal for HCHO, ethanal for CH₃CHO).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The suffix '-ol' is used for alcohols, '-one' for ketones, and '-oic acid' for carboxylic acids. The correct suffix for aldehydes is '-al'.

questions.question_text: The IUPAC name of CH₂=CHCH₂OH is:
questions.explanation_correct: The longest chain has 3 carbons (prop-). The double bond is between C-2 and C-3 (-2-en-) and the hydroxyl group is on C-1 (-1-ol). Numbering gives the lowest locant to the principal characteristic group (OH). Hence, prop-2-en-1-ol.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Allyl alcohol is a common name, not IUPAC. '2-Propenol' omits the position of the OH group. 'Vinyl methanol' is not a valid IUPAC name.

questions.question_text: The IUPAC name of (CH₃)₃CCH₂CH(CH₃)₂ is:
questions.explanation_correct: The longest carbon chain has 5 carbons (pentane). There are three methyl substituents at positions 2, 2, and 4 (numbering to give the lowest set of locants). The correct IUPAC name is 2,2,4-trimethylpentane.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 2,4,4-Trimethylpentane does not give the lowest set of locants (2,2,4 < 2,4,4). 2,2,4-Trimethylbutane incorrectly identifies only 4 carbons in the parent chain. Isooctane is a common name.

questions.question_text: Which of the following functional groups has the highest priority in IUPAC naming?
questions.explanation_correct: In IUPAC nomenclature, carboxylic acid (–COOH) has the highest priority among the given functional groups. The priority order is: –COOH > –CHO > C=O > –OH.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The priority order for principal characteristic groups in IUPAC naming is: carboxylic acid > aldehyde > ketone > alcohol. Therefore, –COOH takes precedence over all the other options listed.

questions.question_text: The IUPAC name of the compound CH₃CH=CHCOOH is:
questions.explanation_correct: The longest chain containing both the double bond and –COOH has 4 carbons (but-). The –COOH is at C-1 (implied for acids), and the double bond is between C-2 and C-3. The IUPAC name is but-2-enoic acid.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Crotonic acid is a common name. '2-Butenoic acid' uses older formatting without specifying 'but-'. 'But-3-enoic acid' incorrectly places the double bond at position 3-4, which does not match the structure.

questions.question_text: Which of the following compounds is classified as a heterocyclic compound?
questions.explanation_correct: Furan is a five-membered heterocyclic compound containing one oxygen atom in the ring along with four carbon atoms. Heterocyclic compounds contain at least one heteroatom (non-carbon atom) in the ring.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cyclohexane, benzene, and naphthalene are all homocyclic (carbocyclic) compounds — their rings consist entirely of carbon atoms. Only furan has a heteroatom (oxygen) in the ring.

questions.question_text: An organic compound contains only C, H, and O. Its molecular formula is C₃H₆O. The degree of unsaturation (index of hydrogen deficiency) is:
questions.explanation_correct: Degree of unsaturation = (2C + 2 + N − H − X) / 2 = (2×3 + 2 − 6) / 2 = 2/2 = 1. Oxygen does not appear in the formula. This indicates one degree of unsaturation — either one double bond or one ring.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using the formula (2C + 2 − H)/2 (oxygen is not counted), we get (6 + 2 − 6)/2 = 1. The compound has exactly one degree of unsaturation, ruling out 0, 2, and 3.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an example of a functional group isomer of ethanol (C₂H₅OH)?
questions.explanation_correct: Methoxymethane (dimethyl ether, CH₃OCH₃) has the same molecular formula (C₂H₆O) as ethanol but contains a different functional group (ether vs. alcohol). This makes them functional group isomers.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Propan-1-ol has a different molecular formula (C₃H₈O). Ethanal (CH₃CHO) has the formula C₂H₄O (different from C₂H₆O). Ethane (C₂H₆) contains no oxygen. Only dimethyl ether shares the formula C₂H₆O with ethanol.

questions.question_text: Which type of isomerism is exhibited by but-1-ene and but-2-ene?
questions.explanation_correct: But-1-ene and but-2-ene have the same molecular formula (C₄H₈) and the same functional group (C=C double bond) but differ in the position of the double bond along the carbon chain. This is position isomerism.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Chain isomerism involves different carbon skeletons. Functional group isomerism involves different functional groups. Geometrical isomerism involves restricted rotation around a double bond. Here, only the position of the double bond differs.

questions.question_text: Geometrical (cis-trans) isomerism requires:

options.text: Free rotation about a single bond
Restricted rotation and two different groups on each doubly bonded carbon
Presence of an asymmetric carbon atom
A triple bond in the molecule

questions.explanation_correct: Geometrical isomerism requires (1) restricted rotation, which is provided by a C=C double bond or a ring, and (2) each carbon of the double bond must carry two different substituents.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Free rotation about single bonds does not lead to geometrical isomers. An asymmetric carbon is required for optical isomerism. A triple bond has a linear geometry and cannot show cis-trans isomerism.

questions.question_text: Tautomerism is most commonly observed between which pair of functional groups?
questions.explanation_correct: Tautomerism is a dynamic equilibrium between two structural isomers that interconvert by the movement of a proton. The most common type is keto-enol tautomerism, seen in compounds like acetone and acetaldehyde.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Alcohol-ether pairs are functional group isomers, not tautomers. Aldehyde and ketone are different compound classes. Amine and amide differ in molecular formula. Keto-enol tautomerism is the most widely studied form.

questions.question_text: How many structural isomers are possible for the molecular formula C₄H₁₀?
questions.explanation_correct: C₄H₁₀ has two structural isomers: n-butane (a straight chain) and isobutane (2-methylpropane, a branched chain). These are chain isomers.
questions.explanation_incorrect: There are exactly two ways to arrange 4 carbon atoms in a saturated hydrocarbon: as a straight chain (butane) and as a branched chain (2-methylpropane). No other connectivity is possible.

questions.question_text: Which of the following compounds can exhibit optical isomerism?
questions.explanation_correct: 2-Bromobutane (CH₃CHBrCH₂CH₃) has an asymmetric (chiral) carbon at C-2, bonded to four different groups (H, Br, CH₃, C₂H₅). This allows it to exist as two enantiomers and show optical activity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 2-Bromopropane has C-2 bonded to two identical methyl groups — no chirality. 1-Bromopropane has no carbon with four different substituents. 2,2-Dibromopropane has two identical bromine atoms on C-2. Only 2-bromobutane has a chiral centre.

questions.question_text: Diethyl ether (C₂H₅OC₂H₅) and methyl propyl ether (CH₃OC₃H₇) are examples of:
questions.explanation_correct: Metamerism is a type of structural isomerism where compounds of the same molecular formula differ in the distribution of carbon atoms on either side of the functional group. Diethyl ether (C₂H₅–O–C₂H₅) and methyl propyl ether (CH₃–O–C₃H₇) both have the formula C₄H₁₀O and the ether functional group but differ in the alkyl groups attached to oxygen.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Position isomers differ in the position of the same functional group on the same chain. Chain isomers differ in the carbon skeleton. Functional group isomers have different functional groups. Here, the same functional group (ether) has different alkyl group distributions — this is metamerism.

questions.question_text: Which of the following compounds shows geometrical isomerism?
questions.explanation_correct: But-2-ene (CH₃CH=CHCH₃) has two different groups on each doubly bonded carbon (H and CH₃ on each), satisfying the conditions for geometrical isomerism. It exists as cis-but-2-ene and trans-but-2-ene.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ethene has two identical H atoms on each carbon of the double bond. Propene has two H atoms on one of the doubly bonded carbons. 2-Methylpropene has two identical methyl groups on one carbon. None of these can show cis-trans isomerism.

questions.question_text: A compound with molecular formula C₅H₁₀ does not decolourise bromine water. The compound is most likely:
questions.explanation_correct: C₅H₁₀ has one degree of unsaturation, which could be a double bond or a ring. Since the compound does not decolourise bromine water, it lacks a C=C double bond. Cyclopentane is a cyclic alkane that does not react with bromine water under normal conditions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Pent-1-ene, pent-2-ene, and 2-methylbut-1-ene all contain C=C double bonds and would readily decolourise bromine water via addition reactions. Only cyclopentane, which satisfies the unsaturation through a ring, would not react.

questions.question_text: The number of chiral centres in the molecule 2,3-dibromobutane is:
questions.explanation_correct: In 2,3-dibromobutane (CH₃CHBrCHBrCH₃), both C-2 and C-3 are chiral centres. Each is bonded to four different groups: H, Br, CH₃, and CHBrCH₃. This gives rise to a pair of enantiomers and a meso form.
questions.explanation_incorrect: C-2 is bonded to H, Br, CH₃, and CHBrCH₃ — four different groups — making it chiral. Similarly, C-3 also has four different substituents. Therefore, there are 2 chiral centres, not 0, 1, or 3.

questions.question_text: Meso compounds are optically inactive despite having chiral centres because they possess:

options.text: A centre of symmetry or an internal plane of symmetry
An odd number of carbon atoms

questions.explanation_correct: Meso compounds contain chiral centres but are optically inactive due to the presence of an internal plane of symmetry (or a centre of symmetry). The rotation caused by one chiral centre is exactly cancelled by the other.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Meso compounds do contain functional groups and can have any number of carbons. Having only sp³ carbons is not the reason for optical inactivity. The key feature is the internal symmetry element that makes the molecule superimposable on its mirror image.

questions.question_text: The inductive effect involves the displacement of:

options.text: Pi electrons in a conjugated system
Sigma electrons along a chain of atoms
Electrons between atomic orbitals of the same atom

questions.explanation_correct: The inductive effect is the permanent displacement (polarisation) of sigma-bond electrons along a chain of atoms due to the presence of an electronegative or electropositive atom or group. It is transmitted through sigma bonds and decreases rapidly with distance.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Pi electron displacement in conjugated systems is the resonance (mesomeric) effect. Non-bonding electron movement relates to lone pair donation. The inductive effect specifically involves sigma-bond electron displacement.

questions.question_text: Which of the following groups exhibits a positive inductive (+I) effect?
questions.explanation_correct: Alkyl groups such as –CH₃ exhibit a +I effect, meaning they donate electron density through sigma bonds toward the rest of the molecule. This is why alkyl groups stabilise carbocations and increase the basicity of amines.
questions.explanation_incorrect: –NO₂, –COOH, and –Cl are all electron-withdrawing groups that exhibit a −I effect. Only alkyl groups (like –CH₃, –C₂H₅) are common +I groups.

questions.question_text: Resonance structures differ in the arrangement of:
questions.explanation_correct: Resonance structures (contributing structures) have the same arrangement of atoms but differ only in the distribution of pi electrons and lone pairs. The actual molecule is a hybrid of all contributing structures.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If atoms were rearranged, the structures would be different compounds (isomers), not resonance structures. Sigma bonds remain unchanged in resonance. Only the pi electrons and lone pairs are redistributed.

questions.question_text: Hyperconjugation is most significant in stabilising:

options.text: Carbocations adjacent to C–H bonds on alpha carbons
Free radicals with no alpha hydrogens

questions.explanation_correct: Hyperconjugation (no-bond resonance) involves delocalisation of electrons from C–H sigma bonds on carbons alpha to the electron-deficient centre. It is most significant in stabilising carbocations: the more alpha C–H bonds, the greater the hyperconjugative stabilisation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Carbanions are stabilised by electron-withdrawing groups through inductive/resonance effects. Free radicals with no alpha hydrogens cannot undergo hyperconjugation. Isolated double bonds without adjacent C–H bonds do not benefit from hyperconjugation.

questions.question_text:
Among the following carboxylic acids, which is the strongest acid?

I. CH₃COOH
II. ClCH₂COOH
III. Cl₂CHCOOH
IV. Cl₃CCOOH
questions.explanation_correct: Trichloroacetic acid (Cl₃CCOOH) is the strongest because three chlorine atoms exert a strong cumulative −I (electron-withdrawing) effect, greatly stabilising the carboxylate anion formed after deprotonation. More electron-withdrawing groups increase acidity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The −I effect of chlorine atoms stabilises the conjugate base. With more Cl atoms, the −I effect increases: Cl₃CCOOH > Cl₂CHCOOH > ClCH₂COOH > CH₃COOH in acid strength.

questions.question_text: The electromeric effect differs from the inductive effect because it is:

options.text: Permanent and operates through sigma bonds
Temporary and involves complete transfer of pi electrons to one atom
Permanent and involves delocalisation of pi electrons
Temporary and operates through sigma bonds

questions.explanation_correct: The electromeric effect is a temporary effect that occurs only in the presence of an attacking reagent. It involves the complete transfer of shared pi electrons to one of the atoms of a multiple bond, unlike the permanent polarisation seen in the inductive effect.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The inductive effect is permanent and operates through sigma bonds. Resonance is permanent delocalisation of pi electrons. The electromeric effect is specifically temporary and involves pi electron transfer, triggered by the approach of a reagent.

questions.question_text: In aniline (C₆H₅NH₂), the lone pair on nitrogen is involved in resonance with the benzene ring. This results in:

options.text: Increased basicity compared to aliphatic amines
Decreased basicity compared to aliphatic amines

questions.explanation_correct: In aniline, the nitrogen lone pair is delocalised into the benzene ring by resonance (+M effect). This makes the lone pair less available for donation to a proton (acid), thereby decreasing the basicity of aniline compared to aliphatic amines like methylamine.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Resonance delocalisation of the nitrogen lone pair into the ring reduces electron density on nitrogen. This decreases both basicity and nucleophilicity at nitrogen, not increases them.

questions.question_text: The correct order of −I effect of the following groups is:
questions.explanation_correct: The −I (electron-withdrawing inductive) effect order is: –NO₂ > –CN > –COOH > –F > –Cl > –Br > –I > –OH > –NH₂. The nitro group is the strongest electron-withdrawing group by inductive effect among common substituents.
questions.explanation_incorrect: –NH₂ and –OH are weakly electron-withdrawing by inductive effect (they are +M groups but −I groups). The correct order places –NO₂ as the strongest −I group. Option A correctly ranks these groups.

questions.question_text: Hyperconjugation can explain all of the following EXCEPT:

options.text: Shortening of C–C bond adjacent to C=C in propene
Greater stability of trans-but-2-ene over cis-but-2-ene

questions.explanation_correct: The acidity of carboxylic acids is primarily explained by resonance stabilisation of the carboxylate anion and the inductive effect of substituents — not by hyperconjugation. Hyperconjugation explains carbocation stability, bond length anomalies, and the relative stability of alkene isomers.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Hyperconjugation explains carbocation stability (more alpha H atoms = more hyperconjugative structures), the shortening of C–C bond length in propene, and the greater stability of more substituted alkenes. However, it does not account for carboxylic acid acidity.

questions.question_text: Resonance energy of benzene is approximately:
questions.explanation_correct: The resonance energy of benzene is approximately 150 kJ/mol (36 kcal/mol). This is the difference between the experimentally determined heat of hydrogenation and the theoretical value calculated for the hypothetical cyclohexatriene with three isolated double bonds.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 36 kJ/mol is too low (this is the value in kcal/mol, which is approximately 150 kJ/mol when converted). 250 kJ/mol and 450 kJ/mol are significantly higher than the actual resonance energy of benzene.

questions.question_text: A carbocation is an organic species in which carbon bears:

options.text: A lone pair of electrons and a negative charge
A positive charge and an empty p orbital
Two non-bonding electrons in a singlet state

questions.explanation_correct: A carbocation is a positively charged carbon species with only three bonds and an empty p orbital. The carbon is sp² hybridised and has a planar geometry. Carbocations are electrophilic (electron-deficient).
questions.explanation_incorrect: A lone pair with a negative charge describes a carbanion. An unpaired electron describes a free radical. Two non-bonding electrons in a singlet state describes a singlet carbene. A carbocation has a positive charge and an empty p orbital.

questions.question_text: The correct stability order of carbocations is:
questions.explanation_correct: Carbocation stability increases with the number of alkyl groups attached to the positively charged carbon: tertiary (3°) > secondary (2°) > primary (1°) > methyl. This is due to the +I effect and hyperconjugation from alkyl groups.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Alkyl groups stabilise carbocations through electron donation (+I effect) and hyperconjugation. More alkyl groups provide greater stabilisation. The correct order is: (CH₃)₃C⁺ (3°) > (CH₃)₂CH⁺ (2°) > CH₃CH₂⁺ (1°) > CH₃⁺ (methyl).

questions.question_text: Free radicals are species that contain:
questions.explanation_correct: Free radicals are electrically neutral species that contain one or more unpaired electrons. They are formed by homolytic cleavage of covalent bonds, where each fragment retains one electron.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A positive charge describes a carbocation. A negative charge describes a carbanion. An empty p orbital is characteristic of carbocations. Free radicals are neutral species with an unpaired electron.

questions.question_text: Which of the following carbanions is most stable?
questions.explanation_correct: Carbanion stability is opposite to carbocation stability: methyl > primary > secondary > tertiary. Alkyl groups are electron-donating (+I effect), which destabilises the negative charge on the carbanion. Fewer alkyl groups mean less electron donation and greater stability.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Unlike carbocations, carbanions are destabilised by electron-donating alkyl groups. The +I effect of alkyl groups increases electron density on the already negatively charged carbon, reducing stability. Hence CH₃⁻ (methyl) is the most stable.

questions.question_text: A carbene is a divalent carbon species. In a singlet carbene, the two non-bonding electrons are:

options.text: In two different orbitals with parallel spins
In the same orbital with paired (antiparallel) spins

questions.explanation_correct: In a singlet carbene, both non-bonding electrons occupy the same sp² orbital with paired (antiparallel) spins. The carbon is sp² hybridised with a vacant p orbital. In contrast, a triplet carbene has unpaired electrons in two different orbitals.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Parallel spins in different orbitals describe a triplet carbene. The electrons are localised on the carbene carbon, not delocalised. A dication would have lost two electrons entirely. In a singlet carbene, the electrons are paired in one orbital.

questions.question_text: Allyl carbocation (CH₂=CH–CH₂⁺) is more stable than a simple primary carbocation because of:

options.text: Inductive effect of the vinyl group
Resonance stabilisation involving delocalisation of the positive charge
Steric shielding of the positive charge

questions.explanation_correct: The allyl carbocation is stabilised by resonance. The positive charge is delocalised over two carbon atoms through conjugation with the adjacent C=C pi bond: CH₂=CH–CH₂⁺ ↔ ⁺CH₂–CH=CH₂. This resonance stabilisation makes it more stable than simple primary carbocations.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While inductive and hyperconjugation effects may contribute slightly, the primary source of stability is resonance delocalisation of the positive charge across the allylic system. Steric shielding does not stabilise charges.

questions.question_text: The benzyl carbocation (C₆H₅CH₂⁺) is unusually stable because:

options.text: The phenyl group has a strong +I effect
The positive charge is delocalised into the benzene ring through resonance
It has no hydrogen atoms on the positively charged carbon

questions.explanation_correct: The benzyl carbocation is stabilised by resonance with the benzene ring. The positive charge on the benzylic carbon is delocalised into the ring through several contributing structures, spreading the charge over multiple atoms and lowering the energy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The phenyl group actually has a slight −I effect. The absence of H atoms on the charged carbon is irrelevant to stability. The benzene ring is electron-rich, not electron-deficient. The key factor is resonance delocalisation of the positive charge.

questions.question_text: Heterolytic cleavage of a C–Br bond in (CH₃)₃CBr produces:

options.text: A free radical and a bromine atom
A tertiary carbocation and a bromide ion

questions.explanation_correct: In heterolytic cleavage, the bonding electron pair goes entirely to one of the two atoms. Since Br is more electronegative, it retains both electrons forming Br⁻, while the carbon becomes a carbocation: (CH₃)₃C⁺. The tertiary carbocation formed is relatively stable.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Homolytic cleavage (not heterolytic) would produce radicals. In heterolytic cleavage of C–Br, bromine takes both electrons because it is more electronegative, forming Br⁻ and a carbocation. A carbanion and Br⁺ would require the reverse electron transfer.

questions.question_text: Homolytic fission of a covalent bond produces:
questions.explanation_correct: In homolytic fission, the shared pair of electrons is divided equally between the two atoms, with each atom retaining one electron. This produces two free radicals, which are electrically neutral species with unpaired electrons.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ions are produced by heterolytic fission, where one atom takes both bonding electrons. Homolytic fission gives each atom one electron, producing neutral free radicals, not ions or ionic compounds.

questions.question_text: Among the following reaction intermediates, which one is planar and has an empty p orbital perpendicular to the plane?
questions.explanation_correct: A carbocation is sp² hybridised with a trigonal planar geometry and a vacant p orbital perpendicular to the molecular plane. While free radicals are also approximately planar (sp² hybridised), the p orbital in a free radical contains one electron — it is not empty. In a carbocation, the p orbital is completely empty.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Carbanions are sp³ hybridised with a pyramidal geometry (or sp² in some stabilised cases). Free radicals are nearly planar but their p orbital contains one unpaired electron, not empty. Only the carbocation has a truly empty p orbital perpendicular to its planar structure.

questions.question_text: Which purification technique is used to separate a mixture of two miscible liquids with a boiling point difference of more than 25°C?
questions.explanation_correct: Simple distillation is effective when the boiling point difference between two miscible liquids is more than 25°C (some sources say 25 K). The liquid with the lower boiling point vapourises first and is collected as the distillate.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Fractional distillation is used when the boiling point difference is less than 25°C. Steam distillation is for separating steam-volatile, water-immiscible compounds. Vacuum distillation is for liquids that decompose at their normal boiling points.

questions.question_text: Lassaigne's test is used to detect the presence of:

options.text: All elements in an organic compound

questions.explanation_correct: In Lassaigne's test, the organic compound is fused with sodium metal to convert covalently bonded N, S, and halogens into ionic forms (NaCN, Na₂S, NaX). These are then detected by specific chemical tests on the sodium fusion extract.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Carbon and hydrogen are detected by combustion analysis (Liebig's method). Oxygen detection requires separate methods. Lassaigne's test specifically converts N, S, and halogens to water-soluble ionic compounds for qualitative detection.

questions.question_text: Column chromatography separates components based on:

options.text: Differential adsorption on the stationary phase

questions.explanation_correct: Column chromatography separates mixture components based on their differential adsorption on a stationary phase (such as silica gel or alumina). Components that are more strongly adsorbed move slower, while weakly adsorbed ones elute faster.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Boiling point differences are exploited in distillation. Melting point differences are used in crystallisation. Density differences are used in centrifugation. Chromatography relies on differential adsorption or partition.

questions.question_text: In the Dumas method for nitrogen estimation, nitrogen in an organic compound is converted to:
questions.explanation_correct: In the Dumas method, the organic compound is heated with excess CuO in a CO₂ atmosphere. Nitrogen in the compound is converted to N₂ gas, which is collected over concentrated KOH solution (to absorb CO₂) and measured volumetrically.
questions.explanation_incorrect: NH₃ gas is produced in the Kjeldahl method. NO₂ is not the target product. NaCN is formed in Lassaigne's test (qualitative). The Dumas method specifically yields N₂ gas for quantitative measurement.

questions.question_text: Sublimation can be used to purify which of the following?
questions.explanation_correct: Naphthalene is a sublimable solid — it directly converts from solid to vapour when heated, bypassing the liquid phase. Sublimation is used to separate sublimable substances (like naphthalene, camphor, iodine) from non-sublimable impurities.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sodium chloride, glucose, and urea do not sublime under normal conditions. They would decompose or melt before subliming. Naphthalene readily sublimes and can be purified by this method.

questions.question_text: In the Carius method, sulphur present in an organic compound is estimated as:
questions.explanation_correct: In the Carius method, the organic compound is heated with fuming nitric acid in a sealed tube. Sulphur is oxidised to sulphuric acid, which is then precipitated as barium sulphate (BaSO₄) by adding barium chloride solution. The BaSO₄ precipitate is weighed to calculate the percentage of sulphur.
questions.explanation_incorrect: SO₂ is a gas that would escape and is difficult to measure accurately. Na₂SO₄ and H₂SO₃ are not precipitated for gravimetric analysis. The Carius method specifically converts sulphur to BaSO₄, a stable, insoluble precipitate that can be accurately weighed.

questions.question_text: Steam distillation is used for purifying organic compounds that are:

options.text: Completely miscible with water and volatile
Miscible with water and have high boiling points

questions.explanation_correct: Steam distillation is used to purify organic liquids that are immiscible with water, are steam-volatile, and have high boiling points. The mixture distils at a temperature below 100°C, preventing decomposition of heat-sensitive compounds like aniline.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If the compound were miscible with water, separation by steam distillation would not work effectively. Non-volatile compounds would not co-distil with steam. Steam distillation requires the compound to be immiscible with water and sufficiently volatile to be carried over by steam.

questions.question_text: An organic compound contains 40% carbon, 6.7% hydrogen, and 53.3% oxygen by mass. Its empirical formula is:
questions.explanation_correct: Dividing percentages by atomic masses: C = 40/12 = 3.33, H = 6.7/1 = 6.7, O = 53.3/16 = 3.33. Dividing by the smallest ratio (3.33): C:H:O = 1:2:1. The empirical formula is CH₂O.
questions.explanation_incorrect: C₂H₄O₂ is the molecular formula of acetic acid, not the simplest ratio. CHO has the wrong hydrogen ratio. CH₃O has too many hydrogens. The calculation gives C:H:O = 1:2:1, so the empirical formula is CH₂O.

questions.question_text: In paper chromatography, the Rf value of a compound is defined as:

options.text: Distance moved by solvent front / Distance moved by solute
Distance moved by solute / Distance moved by solvent front
Mass of solute / Mass of solvent
Concentration of solute in stationary phase / Concentration in mobile phase

questions.explanation_correct: The retention factor (Rf) is defined as the ratio of the distance travelled by the solute (compound spot) to the distance travelled by the solvent front from the origin. Rf values range from 0 to 1 and are characteristic of a compound under given conditions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Rf value is specifically the distance of the solute divided by the distance of the solvent front, not the inverse. It is not a mass or concentration ratio. Rf = distance moved by solute / distance moved by solvent front.

questions.question_text: In Kjeldahl's method for nitrogen estimation, the organic compound is heated with concentrated H₂SO₄. The nitrogen is converted to:
questions.explanation_correct: In Kjeldahl's method, the organic compound is digested with concentrated H₂SO₄ in the presence of a catalyst (K₂SO₄ + CuSO₄). Nitrogen is converted to ammonium sulphate [(NH₄)₂SO₄]. This is then treated with excess NaOH to liberate NH₃, which is absorbed in known excess acid and back-titrated.
questions.explanation_incorrect: N₂ gas is produced in the Dumas method, not Kjeldahl's. HNO₃ and NaNO₃ are not the products of acid digestion with H₂SO₄. Kjeldahl's method specifically converts nitrogen to (NH₄)₂SO₄.
